review.title: On Distributive Subalgebras of Qualitative Spatial and Temporal Calculi
review.abstract: Qualitative calculi play a central role in representing and reasoning about qualitative spatial and temporal knowledge. This paper studies distributive subalgebras of qualitative calculi, which are subalgebras in which (weak) composition distributives over nonempty intersections. It has been proven for RCC5 and RCC8 that path consistent constraint network over a distributive subalgebra is always minimal and globally consistent (in the sense of strong $n$-consistency) in a qualitative sense. The well-known subclass of convex interval relations provides one such an example of distributive subalgebras. This paper first gives a characterisation of distributive subalgebras, which states that the intersection of a set of $n\geq 3$ relations in the subalgebra is nonempty if and only if the intersection of every two of these relations is nonempty. We further compute and generate all maximal distributive subalgebras for Point Algebra, Interval Algebra, RCC5 and RCC8, Cardinal Relation Algebra, and Rectangle Algebra. Lastly, we establish two nice properties which will play an important role in efficient reasoning with constraint networks involving a large number of variables.
histories: Adding proof of Theorem 2 to appendix
review.COMMENTS: Adding proof of Theorem 2 to appendix

sections.heading: 2 Qualitative Calculi
sections.text: In this section we first recall the qualitative calculations PA, IA, CRA, RCC5 / 8 and RA, and then recall some relevant terms and results of these constraint languages. Suppose U is a domain of spatial or temporal units. Let us write Rel (U) for the Boolean algebra of binary relations to U. A qualitative calculation [19] M on U is defined as the finite Boolean subalgebra of Rel (U) having an atom that contains the identity relationship idU on U and is inversely closed, i.e. R is inM iff its converseR − 1 = {(a, b) female U × U: (b, a) female subalgebra of Rel (U) is inM [19]. A relationship α in a qualitative calculation idU on U is atomic or simple if it is an atom inM.

sections.heading: 2.2 RCC5 and RCC8
sections.text: The RCC5 / 8 Constraint Language is a fragment of the Region Connection Calculus (RCC) [22]. RCC is a first-order theory that is based on a binary cross-linking relationship and defines canonical models of connected topological spaces [25,16]. Since applications in GIS and many other spatial reasoning tasks mainly take into account objects represented at the real level, we interpret regions in this paper as non-empty regular closed sentences or regions at the real level and say that two regions are connected when they have non-empty intersections. sections.heading: 3 Distributive Subalgebras
sections.text: Definition 6. [15] Let M be a qualitative calculation. A subclass S of M is called subalgebra if S contains all the basic relationships and is closed under reverse, weak composition and intersection. A subalgebra S is distributed if weak composition is distributed over non-empty intersections of relationships in S, i.e. R (S-T) = (R-T) and (S-T) R = (S-R) for all R, S, T-S with S-T 6 =. Suppose X is a subclass of M. We write X for the subalgebra of M generated by X, i.e. X-T is the closure of X-inM under intersection, weak composition and inversion. Specifically, B-B denotes the closure of B in M.Proposition 3. LetM is one of the calculations PA, IA, RCC5 / 8, CRA, RA, and B the set of basic relationships of M. This subalgebra M is then well-defined by B.

sections.heading: 3.1 Distributive Subalgebra Is Helly
sections.text: Helly's theorem [7] is a very useful result in discrete geometry. For n convex subsets of R, it says that if the intersection of two of these subsets is not empty, then the intersection of the entire collection is not empty either. Interestingly, relationships in a distributing subalgebra have a property similar to convex sets in the real line, and beyond that, relationships with such a property are exactly those in a distributing subalgebra. Definition 7. A subclass S of a qualitative calculation is called helly if for all R, S, T, T, S, S, S, etc., the relationship between R, S, etc., havev, S, etc. - S, etc., if it is a subalgebra. (8) If S is a subalgebra, then it is easy to prove that S, etc. (S, T, etc.) Helly is helly if and only if all relationships are subalgebra, RS, etc.

sections.heading: 3.2 Path Consistency Implies Weakly Global Consistency
sections.text: Theorem 2. Let M be a qualitative calculation that satisfies (6) and (7). Suppose S is a distributive subalgebra of M. Then every path-consistent network over S is weakly globally consistent and minimal; this result was first proven for RCC5 / 8 in [15]. If every path-consistent network over S is consistent, then, after the evidence in [15, Theorem 18], we can show that every path-consistent network over S is also globally weakly consistent and minimal. From the analysis in the following section, we can easily see that this is true for PA, IA, CRA, RA, and RCC5 / 8. To show the general case, the proof is given in the appendix.

sections.heading: 4 Maximal Distributive Subalgebras
sections.text: A distributing subalgebra S is maximum if there is no other distributing subalgebra that correctly contains S. In this section we calculate and list all the maximum distributing subalgebras for RA, IA, CRA, RA and RCC5 / 8.

Fortunately, the result shows that there are exactly two disjointed subsets of X and Y (which form a partition of D), so that each relationship of R, S} fulfills the distribution subrelation of S.

sections.heading: 5 Partial Path Consistency and Variable Elimination
sections.text: In this section, we present two beautiful properties of distributing subalgebras that will play an important role in thinking with large, sparse constraint networks.

sections.heading: 5.1 Variable Elimination
sections.text: In [30], Zhang and Marisetti proposed a novel method of variable elimination to solve (classical and finite) contiguous series convex (CRC) constraints. [8] The idea is to eliminate the variables individually until a trivial problem is reached. Although very simple, the algorithm is able to take advantage of the thrift of problem cases and function very well. A key feature of CRC constraints is that any strong path that affects a consistent CRC constraint network is globally consistent. Remember that a similar property was identified in our theorem 2 for constraint networks via a distributive subalgebra. The following theorem shows that the same variable elimination method can also be applied to constraint networks via a distributive subalgebra.

sections.heading: 5.2 Partial Path Consistency
sections.text: Another efficient method of solving frugal boundary networks is the partial consistency (PPC) algorithms proposed by Bliek and Sam-Haroud. The idea is to force consistency (PC) on frugal graphs (PC). The authors have shown that, as far as CRC constraints are concerned, the boundary capacity of PC on triangulated graphs and their completion is always identical. (PPC has also solved qualitative spatial and temporal constraints [6,23], where the authors have proven that each PPC boundary network is always consistent across a maximum tractable subclass of IA or RCC8. (However, the boundary networks across these subclasses, the boundary capacity of PC on triangulated graphs and their completion are not identical.) In this section, we show that the response to boundary networks via distributed graphs is limited to their boundary capacity, their boundary capacity to PC and their boundary capacity.

sections.heading: 6 Further Discussion
sections.text: In this section we discuss the relationship between distributing subalgebras and conceptual neighbourhood graphs (CNGs) [13] and the star distribution [20] of classical CSPs.

sections.heading: 6.1 Distributive Subalgebras and Conceptual Neighbourhood Graph
sections.text: As we have seen, the classes of convex IA and RCC8 relationships are maximum distribution subalgebras of IA and RCC8, respectively. For IA, ligozate [17] characterizes the convex relationships by using the CNG of IA [13] (shown in Table 1 (ii)). An IA relationship is convex if it is an "interval" [α, β] containing all relations between its two endpoint relationships α, β in CNG. The subclass of convex IA relations is exactly the maximum distribution subalgebra CIA. Similar idea applies to PA and RCC5 directly. For PA, the CNG is shown in the left part of Figure 6 − − and the CNG relations of PA correspond to the "convex" relations in CPA = {< = >,,,, CRA = convective relations of RCCG; one of the maximum distribution subgebras of PA.

sections.heading: 6.2 Relation with Classical CSPs
sections.text: For finite domain CSPs, Montanari observed properties similar to the distribution condition in this paper. In [20], Montanari defined two different concepts related to distribution condition. One is a distribution condition that Xk exhibits, and the other is a star-shaped constraint network. The second concept is very similar to our distribution concept except that it only requires the relationships to form a closure of the network. A constraint network over a distributive subalgebra is always star-shaped, but it is not clear whether a star-shaped network always lies above a distributive subalgebra. As we have seen, relationships in a distributive subalgebra exhibit convexity in the Helly sense. In finite CSP, the convex constraints of the T [27] series and (the more general) tree convexes T are always above a distributive subalgebra.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we have proposed a detailed discussion of the important concept of distributing subalgebra in a recent paper (15). We have shown that the distributing subalgebras are exactly subalgebras that are used in our sense and have found all the maximum distributing subalgebras for PA, IA, RCC5 / 8, CRA and RA. We have also proposed two neat properties of distributing subalgebras that are used for efficient reasoning of the large limited bounding networks. Future work will implement these two methods and compare them empirically by using real datasets.AppendixHere we give a detailed proof of the distributing subalgebras used for a qualitative calculation, the (6) and (7). Suppose S is a distributing subalgebra ofM. Then each path across S is weak globally consistent and minimal.Proof.

metadata.abstractText: Qualitative calculi play a central role in representing and reasoning about qualitative spatial and temporal knowledge. This paper studies distributive subalgebras of qualitative calculi, which are subalgebras in which (weak) composition distributives over nonempty intersections. It has been proven for RCC5 and RCC8 that path consistent constraint network over a distributive subalgebra is always minimal and globally consistent (in the sense of strong n-consistency) in a qualitative sense. The well-known subclass of convex interval relations provides one such an example of distributive subalgebras. This paper first gives a characterisation of distributive subalgebras, which states that the intersection of a set of n ≥ 3 relations in the subalgebra is nonempty if and only if the intersection of every two of these relations is nonempty. We further compute and generate all maximal distributive subalgebras for Point Algebra, Interval Algebra, RCC5 and RCC8, Cardinal Relation Algebra, and Rectangle Algebra. Lastly, we establish two nice properties which will play an important role in efficient reasoning with constraint networks involving a large number of variables.
